awd_titl_txt: Linguistic and Documentation Training for Long Island Algonquian to Support Native American Community Language Researchers
awd_abstract_narration:
The 1990 Native American Languages Act enacted into national policy the recognition of the unique status and importance of Native American languages. Currently, the documentary sources for the indigenous Algonquian languages of Long Island (ALI) and the nearby Southern New England mainland are fragmented and highly challenging, demanding still quite scarce in-depth linguistic expertise to make them of real practical use to scholars and teachers. Collaboratively designed by an indigenous community-member (Unkechaug) Ph.D. researcher, established community language activists, and an experienced Algonquianist linguist, this project will use workshops to make the core tools of Algonquian language analysis and documentation genuinely accessible. Algonquian linguistic structure is notoriously complex, for example, verbs that agree with both subjects and objects (as compared to English, which only displays subject-verb agreement), and further depends on a hierarchy of animacy in subjects and objects in that agreement system. Using a less technical approach, and integrating linguistic research and language revitalization, project activities will develop a richly analyzed and annotated database of ALI materials. Broader impacts include increased participation in the language sciences by Native Americans and support for community language revitalization. Moreover, this research product will be entirely public, supporting work by related Algonquian groups and an existing collaboration with the local K-12 system, even as it sets up the ALI community participants to carry this (and related) research forward as a long-term community effort.


This database developed in this award will generate long-term, sustainable linguistic research infrastructure for the participating Unkechaug, Shinnecock, Montaukett, and Mohegan communities. It will also contribute substantially to the infrastructure of general (and Algonquian-specific) linguistic digital documentation and data analysis, and other fields still unable to use current-form ALI materials. Twelve monthly workshops will offer detechnicalized but rigorous training in the relevant essentials of archival and linguistic data-management, phonetics/phonology, morphosyntax/morphosemantics, historical reconstruction, and other relevant linguistic skills for annotating archival documents, all applied as hands-on work developing the preliminary ALI database. Analysis of entry, mid-project, and exit interviews with participants, and of the training presentation and content itself, provides a final set of reports and recommendations regarding the outcomes and overall effectiveness of this researcher training methodology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Native American Nations of Eastern Long Island, New York have not been speaking their original Algonquian languages for many generations. However, documentation of the languages exists, including a word list compiled by Thomas Jefferson, who visited the area in 1791, and a variety of seventeenth- and eighteenth-century publications. The goal of this project was to directly develop long-term local community linguistic research capacity in the indigenous Algonquian languages of Long Island, New York (ALI).  This project did so through a series of workshops, co-designed by ALI community language teachers, that implemented and tested a novel, culturally appropriate and genuinely accessible approach to rigorous linguistic research training, which we offered to members of the Unkechaug, Mohegan, Shinnecock and Montaukett communities.

In helping communities build a long-term, sustainable linguistic research infrastructure on their own terms, this project also helped indigenous communities and outside academic institutions and researchers cultivate and maintain informed and engaged trust: the foundation for successful collaboration now and in the future.

The Long Island Algonquian Community Language Researcher training workshops were held eight times in 2019 and 2020, for three hours each, with 15 to 25 participants each time. A total of 41 individuals participated at least once. Most workshops took place at a community center located near the Unkechaug (Poospatuck) Reservation; since March 2020, 8 workshops were held via videoconference. The great majority of the participants are Native American, while several others are Stony Brook University undergraduate or graduate students.

The chief aim of these workshops was to help Long Island indigenous communities create/develop their own kind(s) of language research approaches: language work that fits into everyday community life and becomes a regular part of it.  Recognizing that until now, much ALI academic research has been effectively inaccessible because it is coded in opaque technical linguistic jargon, these workshops have re-thought and "re-presented" core tools of Algonquian language analysis and documentation in culturally grounded, everyday-language terms.  These tools include the essentials of philological and linguistic data-management, phonetics/phonology, morphosyntax/morphosemantics, historical reconstruction, and manuscript analysis?all applied as hands-on work developing a preliminary database of ALI primary resources and analytical annotations.

Our most stand-out discovery here has been the effectiveness of reframing (and redesigning) academic-analytical approaches in terms of relations: relations between sounds, between words (and parts of words), and between individual Algonquian languages and varieties?as well as considering long-term Relations with language resources, i.e., questions of documentary and archival best practice.  Workshop participants overall seemed to find the Relations-based approach?particularly in the "full-group presentation followed by small-group work" discovery-method pattern we use?to be an appropriate, effective, and engaging way for them to approach their own language research and to share it with other community members.

We also observed that the actual linguistic-research content of the workshops was found by the participants to be fully accessible, intelligible, and of immediate practical interest and use. 

An important offshoot of the small-group model which we brought into the workshops is a set of family-based researcher training activities.  These were originally intended as simple ways to introduce community members to language documentation and reclamation research (puzzles in historical-comparative reconstruction, in spoken phonology vs. manuscript orthography, and in linguistic data management best practice, etc.) for a range of ages. The covered the following knowledge and skills, among others:

 ? Finding, organizing, and long-term-maintaining language information: anything from the oldest manuscripts to the newest teaching/learning materials;

 ? Understanding basic patterns of spoken pronunciation (rhythm, melody, consonants and vowels), and how they tie into re-establishing spoken words from the oral and written traditions of Long Island languages;

 ? Understanding the basic patterns of the makup of words and sentences;

 ? Knowing how to compare and contrast related Algonquian languages (Wampanoag, Lenape, Abenaki, Passamaquoddy-Maliseet, etc.) to help more confidently recover the pronunciations and meanings of Long Island Algonquian words and phrases.
